coredata.dc:title: Collision-induced absorption in molecular gases: an analytical solution
coredata.dc:creator: Moraldi, M.
Vallauri, R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
An analytic solution for the translational two-body contribution to the quadrupole-induced dipole correlation function is presented. It allows one to evaluate the far-infrared collision-induced absorption spectra of molecular systems, composed of quasi-spherical molecules at low density from the knowledge of few parameters derived from different experiments. The comparison with a translational correlation function extracted from the absorption spectrum of gaseous N2, under the same approximations, is also discussed.

Results and conclusions The solution (19) allows the evaluation of the FIR spectrum from the knowledge of few parameters These can be derived from different experiments, namely, the diffusion coefficient D and the hard-sphere diameter o which can be evaluated, for example, from the value of the second virial coefficient. The rotational contribution, which in the present approximation is decoupled from the translational one, is exactly known under the hypothesis of free rotation, both for linear and symmetric-top molecules. A direct test of the translational part of the two-body correlation function is reported in fig. 1. The full curve corresponds to the solution proposed here and has been evaluated by taking the values of a and D corresponding to a N3 system at low density (p = 55 amagat, T = 300 K). a is set to be equal to 3.7 A [14] and D = 0.0033 cm2/^ is derived from the experimental value at room temperature and 1 atm by scaling the density with a I/p law. For comparison we report the "experimental" curves reported by Buontempo et al. [4]; they extracted the transla- tional spectrum by a deconvolution of the FIR spectrum with the rotational part taken from the Raman measure- ment- This translational contribution has been fitted with a lineshape sum of a Lorentzaan and a Gaussian. The two dashed lines represent the two extreme correlation functions that result from such a procedure, according to the experimental accuracy. The agreement is satisfactory, even if a few comments are in order. Firstly the "ex- perimental" exponential decay is somewhat forced by the choice of a Lorentzian lineshape. In some sense it as- sumes a diffusive-like dynamics of two molecules- The present analysis reveals that in the time scale considered this regime is not yet fully reached: in fact the parameter T' is still proportional to t1 at 1 ps. The difference at short time (f =^ 0.2 ps) can be understood in terms of the assumed interaction potential. It is sufficient to re- member that the value of the normalized second moment (i.e. the second derivative of the normalized correlation function at r = 0) is ==15% larger if it is evaluated using an effective Lennard-Jones potential with e/k-Q = 95 K and a = 3-68 A with respect to the value obtained using a hard-sphere model with the same value of a. The discrepan- cy can be understood by considering that the "experimental" correlation function does not contain only the two- body contribution, but many-body terms become important. In conclusion, we have presented a simple model by which the translational contribution to the FIR absorption spectrum can be evaluated analytically. The comparison with the corresponding "experimental" translational cor- relation function at low density is sufficiently good, in view of the assumptions made in extracting this informa- tion from the full spectrum.
